facts.text: Petitions Nos. 220, 222, 240 and 380 to 395 of 1955 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petitions Nos. 220, 222, 240 and 380 to 395 of 1955. Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Petitions heard on 1957 Dec. 10, 11, 12, 13, 17, 18, 19 and 1958 Jan. 7, 8, 9

anchor.surface_text: 1957. Dec. 10, 11, 12, 13, 17, 18, 19. 1958. Jan. 7, 8, 9. Narsa Raju, Advocate-General for the State of Andhra Pradesh and T. M. Sen, for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on 1958 March 11 by Venkatarama Aiyar J. for Das C.J., Venkatarama Aiyar, S.K. Das and Vivian Bose JJ.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. March II. The judgment of Das C. J., Venkatarama Aiyar, S. K. Das and Vivian Bose, JJ. was delivered by Venkatarama Aiyar J.

facts.text: Petitioners are dealers carrying on business in the City of Madras in the sale and purchase of yarn

anchor.surface_text: VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-The petitioners are dealers carrying on business in the City of Madras in the sale and purchase of yarn, and they have filed the present applications under Art. 32

facts.text: Dealers in Andhra placed orders for purchase of yarn with petitioners in Madras

anchor.surface_text: the course of dealings between the parties resulting 1433 in the above sales has been set out in para. 5 in Petition No. 220 of 1955. It is therein stated that the dealers in Andhra would place orders

facts.text: Contracts concluded at Madras, goods delivered ex-godown at Madras, despatched to purchasers in Andhra

anchor.surface_text: that the contracts would be concluded at Madras, that the goods would be delivered ex-godown at Madras and would thereafter be despatched to the purchasers either by lorries or by rail

facts.text: Price of goods paid in Madras

anchor.surface_text: It is said that in all cases price of the goods was paid in Madras. On the above allegations, it is manifest that the sales mentioned therein are not all of the same kind

facts.text: Dispute confined to imposition of tax on Explanation sales

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioners, however, concedes that the dispute in these proceedings is confined to the proposed imposition of tax, in so far as it relates to sales of the character

facts.text: Parliament enacted Andhra State Act 30 of 1953 on September 14, 1953, came into force October 1, 1953

anchor.surface_text: On September 14, 1953, 1434 Parliament enacted the Andhra State Act  30 of 1953 , whereby a separate State called the State of Andhra was constituted incorporating therein territories

facts.text: Madras General Sales Tax Act (Madras 9 of 1939) continued in Andhra under s.53 Andhra State Act

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 53 of the Andhra State Act, the laws in force in the territories in the Andhra State prior to its constitution are to continue to be in force even thereafter

facts.text: Adaptation Order passed on November 12, 1953 substituting Andhra for Madras in Madras Act

anchor.surface_text: in exercise of the power conferred by this section, an Adaptation Order was passed on November 12, 1953, whereby the word Andhra was substituted for the word Madras in the Madras Act.

facts.text: Explanation 2 to definition of sale added by Madras General Sales Tax Amendment Act No.25 of 1947, effective January 1, 1948

anchor.surface_text: By the Madras General Sales Tax  Amendment  Act No. 25 of 1947, a new Explanation was added to the definition of sale , and it is as follows Explanation 2 ... This amendment came into force on January 1, 1948.

facts.text: Board of Revenue Commercial Taxes Andhra State issued notification on July 13, 1954 calling for returns on Explanation sales

anchor.surface_text: Acting on this judgment, the Board of Revenue  Commercial Taxes  Andhra State, issued a  1  1953 S.C.R. 1069.  1438 notification on July 13, 1954, calling upon dealers to submit returns

facts.text: Andhra State issued notices to petitioners on June 30, 1955 to send returns by July 15, 1955

anchor.surface_text: the Andhra State finally issued on June 30, 1955, notices to the petitioners to send their returns of turnover by July 15, 1955, failing which it was stated that assessments

facts.text: Petitions filed on various dates in July and August 1955

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the petitioners have filed the present petitions challenging the validity of the demand made by the Andhra State ... These petitions were filed on various dates in July and August, 1955.

facts.text: Bengal Immunity Company case judgment dated September 6, 1955

anchor.surface_text: While they were pending, the question ... came up again ... By its judgment dated September 6, 1955, this Court held ...

facts.text: State of Andhra filed statement on October 21, 1955 admitting claim unconstitutional per Bengal Immunity

anchor.surface_text: On the decision in The Bengal Immunity Company case 1  it cannot be doubted that the claim of the Andhra State to tax Explanation sales would be unconstitutional, and indeed, that was admitted by the State in a statement filed on October 21, 1955

facts.text: Sales Tax Validation Ordinance No. III of 1956 promulgated January 30, 1956, replaced by Act 7 of 1956 on March 21, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Before final orders were passed on the petitions, however, the Sales Tax Validation Ordinance No. III of 1956, was promulgated on January 30, 1956, and that was later replaced by the Sales Tax Laws Validation Act  7 of 1956  and that came into force on March 21, 1956.

facts.text: Andhra State became State of Andhra Pradesh under s.3(1) States Reorganisation Act 37 of 1956

anchor.surface_text: On February 19, 1957, the Andhra State which had become the State of Andhra Pradesh under s. 3  1  of the States Reorganisation Act  37 of 1956  filed a fresh statement

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh filed fresh statement on February 19, 1957 claiming entitlement to tax per Validation Act

anchor.surface_text: On February 19, 1957, the Andhra State which had become the State of Andhra Pradesh under s. 3  1  of the States Reorganisation Act  37 of 1956  filed a fresh statement that by reason of the Validation Act the State was entitled

facts.text: President issued Fourth Amendment inserting s.22 in Madras Act on July 2, 1952 under Art.372(2)

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power conferred by this provision, 1437 the President made Adaptation Orders ... as regards the Madras Act, he issued on July 2, 1952, the Fourth, Amendment inserting a new section, s. 22 in that Act.

holdings.text: Section 22 of the Madras Act is conditional legislation imposing tax effective upon Parliament lifting the Art.286(2) ban.

anchor.surface_text: In other words, it is a piece of legislation imposing tax in praesenti but with a condition annexed that it is to come into force in futuro as and when Parliament so provides.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid under precedent like Queen v. Burah; s.22 imposes tax suspended till ban lifted; no constitutional bar to conditional legislation.
